docs.lead_paragraph: As mayor, Edward I. Koch would often deflect insults by insisting that he was not, among other things, a ''wacko,'' a ''dope'' or a ''punching bag.'' But he now admits that the taunt that stung most was inflicted well before he acquired a politician's thick skin. As a child, he hated being called ''fatso.'' Worse, still, it was true.

headline.main: Koch Draws On Childhood For a Lesson About Health

docs.abstract: Former New York City mayor, Edward I Koch, and his sister Pat Koch Thaler write cautionary children's book, Eddie Shapes Up, a more or less autobiographical account of youngster who faces down dietary demons and body-image problems to emerge healthy and self-accepting; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As mayor, Edward I. Koch would often deflect insults by insisting that he was not, among other things, a “wacko,” a “dope” or a “punching bag.” But he now admits that the taunt that stung most was inflicted well before he acquired a politician’s thick skin.

headline.main: From Koch, a Child’s Tale of Health and Self-Acceptance

docs.abstract: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch and his sister have written a cautionary children’s book, “Eddie Shapes Up,” a more or less autobiographical account of a youngster who faces down dietary demons to emerge healthy and self-accepting.
